game_overview: Lords of Waterdeep is a strategy board game set in the Dungeons & Dragons universe. Players take on the roles of secret Lords vying for control of Waterdeep, the City of Splendors. You recruit adventurers to complete quests, build new establishments, and use intrigue to gain the upper hand against your rivals. Your Lord identity is secret, granting bonus points for completing certain types of quests.
objective: Score the most Victory Points (VP) by completing Quests, constructing Buildings, playing Intrigue cards, and fulfilling your Lord's secret bonus conditions.

components_overview.name: Game Board
components_overview.description: The city of Waterdeep with various action spaces: Cliffwatch Inn, Aurora's Realms Shop, The Grinning Lion Tavern, Castle Waterdeep, Waterdeep Harbor, Builder's Hall, and Field of Triumph. Also shows the round track (1-8) and building spaces.

components_overview.name: Agents
components_overview.description: Wooden agent tokens in each player color. Start with 4 agents. You do not gain an additional agent in round 5.

components_overview.name: Agents
components_overview.description: Wooden agent tokens in each player color. Start with 2 agents. Gain an additional agent in round 5.

components_overview.name: Adventurer Cubes
components_overview.description: Four types of adventurers: Fighters (orange), Rogues (black), Wizards (purple), Clerics (white). Used to complete quests. Referred to by color in the rules.

components_overview.name: Quest Cards
components_overview.description: Show adventurer requirements, gold cost, rewards, and quest type (Arcana, Commerce, Piety, Skullduggery, Warfare). Completed quests score VP.

components_overview.name: Intrigue Cards
components_overview.description: Special action cards played at Waterdeep Harbor. Three types: Attack (harm opponents), Utility (help yourself), Mandatory Quests (force opponents to complete before their own quests).

components_overview.name: Lord Cards
components_overview.description: 11 secret identity cards. Each Lord scores bonus VP at game end for completing specific quest types or controlling buildings.

components_overview.name: Building Tiles
components_overview.description: 24 purchasable buildings that add new action spaces. Cost 3-8 Gold. Owner gains a bonus when anyone uses their building. Buildings score 4 VP at game end.

components_overview.name: Building Control Markers
components_overview.description: Placed on buildings you own to track ownership. You receive benefits when others use your buildings.

components_overview.name: Gold Tokens
components_overview.description: Currency used to buy buildings, pay quest costs, and activate certain actions. Denominations of 1 and 5.

components_overview.name: Victory Point Tokens
components_overview.description: Tokens for tracking VP beyond 100 on the score track. 100 VP tokens are used when you lap the track.

components_overview.name: Ambassador Token
components_overview.description: Neutral gray agent that can be recruited from Castle Waterdeep. Returns to Castle Waterdeep at the end of each round.

components_overview.name: Lieutenant Token
components_overview.description: Neutral gray agent that can be recruited from Castle Waterdeep. Once recruited, stays with you permanently.

components_overview.name: First Player Marker
components_overview.description: Passed clockwise at the end of each round to indicate who goes first.

components_overview.name: Corruption Track
components_overview.description: Tracks Corruption tokens taken by players. At game end, players lose VP based on total Corruption in play.

components_overview.name: Corruption Tokens
components_overview.description: Negative VP tokens gained from certain powerful actions. The more Corruption in play, the more VP each token costs at game end.

components_overview.name: Skullport Board
components_overview.description: Expansion board with powerful action spaces that often give Corruption as a cost.

components_overview.name: Undermountain Board
components_overview.description: Expansion board with high-reward action spaces for experienced players.

setup.description: Place the game board in the center of the table.
Sort the adventurer cubes by color (orange Fighters, black Rogues, purple Wizards, white Clerics) and place them in the supply near the board.
Create separate supplies for gold tokens and VP tokens near the board.
Shuffle the Quest cards and place them face-down as a draw deck. Draw 4 Quest cards and place them face-up at Cliffwatch Inn.
Shuffle the Intrigue cards and place them face-down as a draw deck near Waterdeep Harbor.
Shuffle the Building tiles (basic game: use only tiles with no expansion symbol) and draw 3. Place them face-up in Builder's Hall.
Place the round marker on space 1 of the round track.
Each player chooses a color and takes: the corresponding tavern card, all agents of that color, the score marker, and building control markers.
Place each player's score marker on space 0 of the VP track.
Shuffle the Lord cards and deal 1 face-down to each player. Look at your Lord secretly and keep it hidden until end of game scoring.
Give each player 4 gold from the supply.
Deal 2 Quest cards face-down to each player. These go in your active quest area (tavern card).
Deal 2 Intrigue cards face-down to each player. Keep these hidden in your hand.
Determine the first player randomly. That player takes the First Player marker.

Give starting resources based on player order: 1st player gets nothing extra, 2nd player gets 1 gold, 3rd player gets 1 gold, 4th player gets 1 gold + 1 adventurer of their choice, 5th player gets 1 gold + 1 adventurer of their choice.
Each player starts with 4 agents instead of 2. Skip gaining the extra agent in round 5.
Each player starts with 2 agents. You will gain an additional agent in round 5.
Place the Corruption Track near the board. Fill all spaces with Corruption tokens from the supply.
Place the Skullport and/or Undermountain expansion boards next to the main board.

gameplay.turn_structure: The game is played over 8 rounds. Each round, players take turns placing one Agent at a time on an available action space and taking that action. After all agents are placed, there is a cleanup phase before the next round.

actions.name: Place an Agent
actions.description: On your turn, place one of your available Agents on an unoccupied action space and immediately take that action.

steps.description: Choose one of your unassigned Agents.
Place it on any unoccupied action space on the board (including player-owned Buildings).
Immediately take the action shown on that space.
If the space is a player-owned Building, the owner gains the bonus shown in the Owner box.

notes.description: Each action space can only hold one Agent (exception: Waterdeep Harbor has 3 spaces).
You MUST take the action when you place an Agent - you cannot skip it.
If you have no Agents left, you pass for the rest of the round.

actions.name: Complete a Quest
actions.description: You may complete one Quest on your turn AFTER placing your Agent, if you have the required adventurers and gold.

steps.description: Choose an active Quest card from your tavern.
Pay the required adventurer cubes (return them to the supply).
Pay any required gold (return to the supply).
Gain the rewards shown on the Quest card (VP, resources, etc.).
Move the completed Quest face-up to your completed quest pile.
If it's a Plot Quest, keep it face-up for its ongoing effect.

notes.description: You may complete only ONE Quest per turn.
You can complete a Quest you just obtained this turn.
Mandatory Quests must be completed before any other Quests.

actions.name: Waterdeep Harbor - Reassign Agent
actions.description: At the end of the round, Agents placed at Waterdeep Harbor are reassigned in order (1, 2, 3).

steps.description: Starting with space 1, each Agent is moved to a different action space.
The owner takes the action at the new space.
The Harbor agent is then returned to its owner.

notes.description: Harbor is the only action that lets you effectively take 2 actions with one Agent.
The Intrigue card is played immediately, but the reassignment happens at end of round.

key_concepts.name: Action Spaces
key_concepts.description: Cliffwatch Inn (3 spaces): Space 1: Take 1 Quest + 2 Gold. Space 2: Take 1 Quest + 1 Intrigue card. Space 3: Discard all face-up Quests, draw new ones, take 1 Quest. Aurora's Realms Shop: Take 4 Gold. The Grinning Lion Tavern: Take 2 Rogues. The Plinth: Take 1 Cleric. Blackstaff Tower: Take 1 Wizard. Castle Waterdeep: Take First Player marker + draw 1 Intrigue card. Builder's Hall: Purchase a Building tile (VP tokens accumulate on tiles each round). Field of Triumph: Take 2 Fighters. Waterdeep Harbor (3 spaces): Play 1 Intrigue card, then reassign your Agent to another space at end of round.

key_concepts.name: Adventurer Types
key_concepts.description: Fighters (Orange): Often needed for Warfare quests. Rogues (Black): Often needed for Skullduggery quests. Wizards (Purple): Often needed for Arcana quests. Clerics (White): Often needed for Piety quests. Commerce quests often need gold or a mix. Cubes are limited - if supply runs out, you cannot gain more of that type.

key_concepts.name: Quest Types
key_concepts.description: Arcana (blue): Magic-focused, often need Wizards. Commerce (yellow): Trade-focused, often need gold/mix. Piety (silver): Religious, often need Clerics. Skullduggery (green): Thievery, often need Rogues. Warfare (red): Military, often need Fighters. Your Lord card grants bonus VP for completing certain quest types.

key_concepts.name: Plot Quests
key_concepts.description: Plot Quests have a scroll symbol. When completed, they provide an ongoing benefit for the rest of the game rather than just VP. Keep completed Plot Quests face-up as a reminder of their ongoing effect.

key_concepts.name: Mandatory Quests
key_concepts.description: Intrigue cards can force opponents to take Mandatory Quests (orange border). A player with a Mandatory Quest MUST complete it before completing any other Quest. They award few VP and distract from your strategy.

key_concepts.name: Buildings
key_concepts.description: Purchase Buildings from Builder's Hall for gold. Place them on an empty Building space on the board. You place a control marker on it. When ANY player (including you) uses your Building, you gain the Owner bonus shown on the tile. Buildings score 4 VP at game end.

key_concepts.name: Lord Bonuses
key_concepts.description: Your secret Lord card provides end-game bonus VP. Most Lords score +4 VP for each completed Quest of 2 specific types. Example: Durnan the Wanderer scores +4 VP per Commerce Quest and +4 VP per Warfare Quest. Keep your Lord secret to avoid telegraphing your strategy.

key_concepts.name: Intrigue Cards
key_concepts.description: Attack cards: Harm opponents or force choices on them. Utility cards: Provide resources, VP, or other benefits to you. Mandatory Quests: Force an opponent to complete a small Quest before their other Quests. Play Intrigue cards at Waterdeep Harbor.

procedure: Complete round 8 including final reassignments from Waterdeep Harbor.
All players reveal their Lord cards.

final_scoring.description: Already scored during the game as you completed Quests.
Score the bonus shown on your Lord card. Most Lords give +4 VP per Quest of 2 specific types.
Score 4 VP for each Building you control.
Score 1 VP for each adventurer cube remaining in your tavern.
Score 1 VP for every 2 gold remaining (rounded down).

winning_condition: The player with the most Victory Points wins. In case of a tie, the tied player with the most gold remaining wins. If still tied, players share the victory.

tips_for_new_players.description: Check your Lord card early and focus on quests that match your bonus. +4 VP per matching quest adds up quickly.
Don't stockpile too many adventurers of one color. Take quests that use what you have.
It's powerful because you play an Intrigue card AND get to place your Agent again at end of round.
Buildings generate VP and ongoing benefits when others use them. Early buildings pay off more.
Their ongoing benefits compound over the game.
If someone is collecting lots of one adventurer type, they're likely going for quests needing that type.
Active Quests don't score until completed. Keep 2-3 active and focus on completing them.
In round 5, everyone gains an extra Agent. Plan for the extra action economy.
You MUST be able to complete an action to place an Agent there. You cannot block spaces you can't use (e.g., Builder's Hall without gold).
You can complete a Quest immediately after taking it from Cliffwatch Inn on the same turn.
Plot Quest VP bonuses only apply to Quests completed AFTER the Plot Quest itself. They don't count themselves.
There are no maximum limits on active Quests, completed Quests, or Intrigue cards in hand.
When reassigning from Waterdeep Harbor, you can NEVER place to another Harbor space.
At the start of each round, place 1 VP token on each Building tile in Builder's Hall. These accumulate and are gained when purchased.
